In this post I use fake hospital data to answer questions using both R and SQL (Structured Query Language) via a R package called RSQLite.

0. Introduction

There are a handful of programming languages that data scientists use when querying, analyzing, and manipulating data. What I have found in my experience, research, and interviews with various companies is that while R and Python have a lot more power in what they are capable of producing, SQL is a fairly common way most people (especially outside of data science) query their data. So to get more practice using SQL (and R) I pulled some data and 10 questions off a website called Learn SQL, and will be answering them in both R and SQL.

0.1 Packages

For all my data quering and manipulation in R I will be using the tidyverse.

library(tidyverse)

To run create a SQL database, and run SQL queries in R chunks I will be using a package called RSQLite.

library(RSQLite)

0.2 Data

This post will use two data sets that I copied from Learn SQL:

  1. patients: Which includes patient_id, first_name, last_name, gender, birth_date, city, province_id, allergies, height, and weight. Note I only copied the first 1000 entries.
patients <- utils::read.csv('../../00_data/patients.csv')
  1. province_names: Which includes province_id, and province_name.
province_names <- utils::read.csv("../../00_data/province_names.csv")

0.3 Database

To start I am using the dbConnect(), and SQLite() functions to create a hospital

Since SQL lets the user access and manipulate data from a database, it is important to create this data base.

Create a Hospital database to store the patients data.

hosp <- RSQLite::dbConnect(RSQLite::SQLite(),
                           "../../00_data/Hospital.db")
RSQLite::dbWriteTable(hosp,
                      "patients",
                      patients)
RSQLite::dbWriteTable(hosp,
                      "province_names",
                      province_names)
RSQLite::dbListTables(hosp)
[1] "patients"       "province_names"

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp, 
                    "SELECT * 
                     FROM patients 
                     LIMIT 10"
                    )

2. Show total patients admitted.

R

base::data.frame("total_admissions" = base::nrow(patients))
  total_admissions
1             1000

SQL

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT COUNT(*) AS total_admissions 
                     FROM patients"
                    )
  total_admissions
1             1000

3. Show first and last name as full_name.

R

utils::head(
  base::data.frame(
    full_name = base::paste0(patients$first_name, 
                             " ", 
                             patients$last_name)), 
  10)
           full_name
1  Donald Waterfield
2      Mickey Baasha
3        Jiji Sharma
4         Blair Diaz
5      Charles Wolfe
6         Sue Falcon
7      Thomas ONeill
8      Sonny Beckett
9     Sister Spitzer
10   Cedric Coltrane

SQL

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
  "SELECT first_name || ' ' || last_name AS full_name 
   FROM patients 
   LIMIT 10"
   )
           full_name
1  Donald Waterfield
2      Mickey Baasha
3        Jiji Sharma
4         Blair Diaz
5      Charles Wolfe
6         Sue Falcon
7      Thomas ONeill
8      Sonny Beckett
9     Sister Spitzer

4 Show unique cities that are in province_id ‘NS’?

R

patients %>% 
  filter(province_id == "NS") %>%
  summarise(unique_cities = unique(city)) 
    unique_cities
1 Port Hawkesbury
2         Halifax

SQL

dbGetQuery(hosp,
           "SELECT DISTINCT(city) AS unique_cities 
            FROM patients 
            WHERE province_id IS 'NS'"
           )
    unique_cities
1 Port Hawkesbury
2         Halifax

5. Show the total amount of male patients and the total amount of female patients.

Display the two results in the same row.

R

base::data.frame(
  male_count = base::length(base::which(patients$gender == 'M')),
  female_count = base::length(base::which(patients$gender == 'F'))
  )
  male_count female_count
1        543          457

SQL

dbGetQuery(hosp,
           "SELECT 
           (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM patients WHERE gender = 'M') AS male_count, 
           (SELECT COUNT(*) FROM patients WHERE gender = 'F') AS female_count")
  male_count female_count
1        543          457

6. Show all allergies ordered by popularity. Remove NULL values from query.

R

patients %>% 
  filter(allergies != "NULL") %>%
  group_by(allergies) %>%
  summarise(total_diagnosis = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(total_diagnosis)) %>%
  head(10)
# A tibble: 10 × 2
   allergies   total_diagnosis
   <chr>                 <int>
 1 Penicillin              230
 2 Codeine                  58
 3 Sulfa                    35
 4 ASA                      16
 5 Sulfa Drugs              13
 6 Tylenol                  11
 7 Wheat                    11
 8 Peanuts                  10
 9 Bee Stings                9
10 Iodine                    9

SQL

dbGetQuery(hosp,
           "SELECT allergies,
            COUNT(*) AS total_diagnosis
            FROM patients
            WHERE allergies IS NOT 'NULL'
            GROUP BY allergies
            ORDER BY total_diagnosis DESC
            LIMIT 10"
           )
     allergies total_diagnosis
1   Penicillin             230
2      Codeine              58
3        Sulfa              35
4          ASA              16
5  Sulfa Drugs              13
6        Wheat              11
7      Tylenol              11
8      Peanuts              10
9       Iodine               9
10  Bee Stings               9

7. Display the total amount of patients for each province. Order by descending.

R

base::merge(province_names, patients, by = "province_id") %>%
  group_by(province_name) %>%
  summarise(patient_count = n()) %>%
  arrange(desc(patient_count))
# A tibble: 8 × 2
  province_name             patient_count
  <chr>                             <int>
1 Ontario                             954
2 Alberta                              14
3 British Columbia                     11
4 Nova Scotia                           9
5 Manitoba                              7
6 Newfoundland and Labrador             2
7 Quebec                                2
8 Saskatchewan                          1

SQL

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT province_name,
                     COUNT(*) as patient_count
                     FROM patients pa
                     join province_names pr on pr.province_id = pa.province_id
                     group by pr.province_id
                     order by patient_count desc")
              province_name patient_count
1                   Ontario           954
2                   Alberta            14
3          British Columbia            11
4               Nova Scotia             9
5                  Manitoba             7
6                    Quebec             2
7 Newfoundland and Labrador             2
8              Saskatchewan             1

8. Show the provinces that has more patients identified as ‘M’ than ‘F’. Must only show full province_name.

R

base::merge(province_names, patients, by = "province_id") %>%
  dplyr::group_by(province_name) %>%
  dplyr::count(gender == "M", gender == "F") %>%
  dplyr::slice(base::which.max(n)) %>%
  dplyr::summarise(province_name = province_name)
# A tibble: 8 × 1
  province_name            
  <chr>                    
1 Alberta                  
2 British Columbia         
3 Manitoba                 
4 Newfoundland and Labrador
5 Nova Scotia              
6 Ontario                  
7 Quebec                   
8 Saskatchewan

SQL

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT pr.province_name
                     FROM patients AS pa
                     JOIN province_names AS pr ON pa.province_id = pr.province_id
                     GROUP BY pr.province_id
                     HAVING
                     COUNT( CASE WHEN gender = 'M' THEN 1 END) >
                     COUNT( CASE WHEN gender = 'F' THEN 1 END)")
              province_name
1                   Alberta
2          British Columbia
3                  Manitoba
4 Newfoundland and Labrador
5               Nova Scotia
6                   Ontario
7                    Quebec
8              Saskatchewan

9. Each admission costs $50 for patients without insurance, and $10 for patients with insurance. All patients with an even patient_id have insurance.

Give each patient a ‘Yes’ if they have insurance, and a ‘No’ if they don’t have insurance. Add up the admission_total cost for each has_insurance group.

R

for(i in 1:length(patients$patient_id))
  {
  if(patients$patient_id[[i]]%%2==1){
     patients$has_insurance[[i]] <- "Yes"
  }else{
    patients$has_insurance[[i]] <- "No"
  }
}

#. patients

SQL

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT 
                        CASE WHEN patient_id % 2 = 0 Then 'Yes'
                        ELSE 'No' 
                        END as has_insurance,
                     SUM(
                        CASE WHEN patient_id % 2 = 0 Then 10
                        ELSE 50 
                        END
                         ) as cost_after_insurance
                     FROM patients 
                     GROUP BY has_insurance;")
  has_insurance cost_after_insurance
1            No                25000
2           Yes                 5000

10. We are looking for a specific patient. Pull all columns for the patient who matches the following criteria:

  • First_name contains an ‘b’ after the first two letters.
  • Identifies their gender as ‘F’
  • Their weight would be between 50kg and 70kg
  • Their patient_id is an odd number
  • They are from the city ‘Burlington’

R

patients %>%
  filter(base::grepl("^.{2}[b]", first_name),
         gender == "F",
         weight > 50 && weight < 80,
         patient_id %%2==1,
         city == "Burlington")
  patient_id first_name last_name gender birth_date       city province_id
1        695    Sabrina    Hettie      F 2000-11-25 Burlington          ON
   allergies height weight has_insurance
1 Penicillin    160     51           Yes

SQL

RSQLite::dbGetQuery(hosp,
                    "SELECT *
                     FROM patients
                     WHERE
                      first_name LIKE '__b%'
                      AND gender = 'F'
                      AND weight BETWEEN 50 AND 70
                      AND patient_id % 2 = 1
                      AND city = 'Burlington';")
  patient_id first_name last_name gender birth_date       city province_id
1        695    Sabrina    Hettie      F 2000-11-25 Burlington          ON
   allergies height weight
1 Penicillin    160     51
